data.text: AIA National Heritage Taskforce Significant 20 th century Qld architecture – places of national significance (a work in progress based on appendix 1 to 2005 report; revised and annotated by Qld sub-committee September 2007, further revised by Qld sub-committee 2009 1 ) CRITERIA FOR SELECTION List based on Fiona Gardiner’s 1988 report to RAIA & AHC, Register of significant 20 th century architecture Qld; buildings included from that study marked (FG) Criteria for other places includes: the wonderful, built works (unbuilt schemes not included), national award winners from Qld Please note this list is not comprehensive, but should be regarded as a ‘first cut’ only eg the list does include a number of, but not all, state award winners - as soon as a complete list of state award winners from 1939 is available, then this group should be systematically considered. LEGEND FG listed in F Gardiner, Register of significant 20 th century architecture Qld. 1988 report to RAIA QHR building entered in Qld Heritage Register (under provisions of Qld Heritage Act 1992) IS considered of international significance N national award winners (taken from architecture.com.au therefore only noted from 1981) *** citations prepared 1 Riddel Architecture, Significant Qld 20 th century architecture, a report to the Qld Chapter of the RAIA 2005. The findings of that report have been endorsed by the Institute. At a meeting of the Qld heritage sub-committee of 17 September 2007 (following a request from the National Heritage Committee) a number of places from the list contained in appendix 1 to the 2005 report were identified as being of national significance. The following places (also considered of national significance) were also added to the list at that meeting: RS Dods & JL Pearson - St John’s Cathedral Precinct (QHR; IS); Hall & Dods - Myendetta, Charleville (NS) and Wyambyn, Tabragalba ; Karl Langer - West’s Furniture Store, Fortitude Valley (1954) and Sugar Research Station, Mackay; JS Murdoch (Q Dept Public Works) - Mackay Customs House (1902) (QHR); RC Nowland (Q Dept Public Works) - University of Qld Medical School, Herston (1939) (QHR); Eddie Oribin - Japanese house, Cairns; Lange Powell - house for EK Brodribb, Gladstone Rd, Dutton Park (1915) and house for Geo Stronach, Eldernell Av, Hamilton (1931); Qld Dept Public Works - Anzac Square (QHR); Harry Seidler – Kooralbyn; AB Wilson - Lamb house, Kangaroo Pt (1901) (QHR). In 2010 the AIA Heritage Taskforce considered nominations from each state for residential places of national significance. Queensland submitted citations (in an agreed format) for 20 places: AB Wilson - Home (Lamb house), Kangaroo Pt; Hall & Dods - Myendetta, Charleville; EP Trewern - Santa Barbara, New Farm; Donoghue & Fulton - fmr Masel house, Stanthorpe; Karl Langer - fmr Langer residence, St Lucia; Hayes & Scott – Graham house, Indooroopilly; Job & Froud - Torbrek, Highgate Hill; John Dalton - Dalton house, Figtree Pocket; John Railton - Wilson house, Dickie Beach; James Birrell – Union College, University of Qld; Rex Addison - Addison house no1, Taringa; Chris Clarke - Clarke house, Ascot; Russel Hall - Carpenter Hall house, Wilston; Lindsay & Kerry Clare - Clare house, Buderim; Gabriel Poole - Poole house, Lake Weyba; Gerry Murtagh – Grant house, Sunshine Beach house; Don Watson - Campbell house, Graceville; Andresen O’Gorman - Mooloomba house, Pt Lookout; Donovan Hill - ‘C’ house, Coorparoo; Elizabeth Watson Brown & Peter Skinner - house, St Lucia. Ultimately the category was defined to not include institutional residential buildings so Union College was excluded. At this point in time, 2 Qld residential places have been included on the AIA list of nationally significant buildings – the homestead Myendetta at Charleville and the ‘C’ house. Riddel Architecture AIA Heritage Taskforce – Significant 20 th century Qld architecture - draft list of nationally significant places (August 2010) 1
